soln_description:
【Sol】Let $y=m^{2}, m \in \mathbb{N}$, then
$$
\begin{array}{c}
(x-36)(x-144)-1991=m^{2}, \\
x^{2}-180 x+3193=m^{2}, \\
(x-90)^{2}-4907=m^{2} .
\end{array}
$$

Let $x-90=k$, then

Therefore,
$$
\begin{array}{c}
k^{2}-m^{2}=4907=7 \cdot 701, \\
(k+m)(k-m)=7 \cdot 701 .
\end{array}
$$

Since 7 and 701 are both prime numbers, and
$$
k-m<k+m \text {, }
$$

we can only get the following four systems of equations.
$\mathrm{I} \cdot\left\{\begin{array}{l}k-m=1, \\ k+m=4907 .\end{array}\right.$
II . $\left\{\begin{array}{l}k-m=7, \\ k+m=701 .\end{array}\right.$
III. $\left\{\begin{array}{l}k-m=-4907, \\ k+m=-1 .\end{array}\right.$
$\mathbb{V} \cdot\left\{\begin{array}{l}k-m=-701, \\ k+m=-7 .\end{array}\right.$

Solving the systems of equations III and IV yields $x$ as a negative integer, which does not meet the problem's requirements.
Solving the systems of equations $\mathrm{I}$, II, we get
$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
k=2454, \\
m=2453 .
\end{array} \text { or } \left\{\begin{array}{l}
k=354, \\
m=347 .
\end{array}\right.\right.
$$

Thus, $x=2544$ or $x=444$, and the corresponding $y=6017209$, or $y=120409$. Therefore, the graph of $y=(x-36)(x-144)-1991$ only passes through the points $(2544, 6017209)$, $(444, 120409)$.
informal_statement:
12.37 In the Cartesian coordinate system $x-o-y$, we color the points with natural number abscissas and perfect square ordinates (squares of natural numbers) as red points. Determine all the "red points" through which the graph of the function $y=(x-36)(x-144)-1991$ passes.
(China Beijing High School Grade 1 Mathematics Competition, 1991)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 12.37 In the Cartesian coordinate system $x-o-y$, we color the points with natural number abscissas and perfect square ordinates (squares of natural numbers) as red points. Determine all the "red points" through which the graph of the function $y=(x-36)(x-144)-1991$ passes.
(China Beijing High School Grade 1 Mathematics Competition, 1991) -/
theorem algebra_226321 (f : ℕ → ℕ) (hf : ∀ x, f x = (x - 36) * (x - 144) - 1991)
    (red_points : Set (ℕ × ℕ)) (hred_points : ∀ x y, (x, y) ∈ red_points ↔
    ∃ n, x = n ∧ ∃ m, y = m ^ 2 ∧ f x = y) :
    red_points = {(2544, 6017209), (444, 120409)} := by

informal_statement: Prove the trigonometric identity: $2\sec^2A - \sec^4A - 2\csc^2A + \csc^4A = \cot^4A - \tan^4A$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped Real

/- Prove the trigonometric identity: $2\sec^2A - \sec^4A - 2\csc^2A + \csc^4A = \cot^4A - \tan^4A$. -/
theorem algebra_5333 (A : Real) :
  2 / (cos A) ^ 2 - 1 / (cos A) ^ 4 - 2 / (sin A) ^ 2 + 1 / (sin A) ^ 4 =
  1 / (tan A) ^ 4 - 1 / (cot A) ^ 4 := by

soln_description:
Three, as shown in Figure 5, $A(3,0)$ is the intersection point of the parabola with the positive half of the $x$-axis. Since
$$
\begin{array}{l}
y=x^{2}-2 x-3 \\
=(x-1)^{2}-4,
\end{array}
$$

the vertex of the original parabola is $P(1,-4)$, and the intersection point of the axis of symmetry with the $x$-axis is $B(1,0)$.
(1) If the original parabola is rotated $90^{\circ}$ clockwise around $A(3,0)$, let the new vertex of the parabola be $P^{\prime}$, and point $B$ rotates to position $B^{\prime}$. Then
$$
B^{\prime} A \perp A B, \triangle P A B \cong \triangle P^{\prime} A B^{\prime} .
$$

Therefore, $\angle B^{\prime}=\angle P B A=90^{\circ}, P^{\prime} B^{\prime}=P B=4$,
$$
B^{\prime} A=B A=O A-O B=3-1=2 \text {. }
$$

It is easy to see that $P^{\prime} B^{\prime} / / x$-axis, and $P^{\prime}$ is in the second quadrant.
Thus, $P^{\prime}(-1,2)$.
According to the vertex form, the equation of the new parabola can be set as
$$
x=a(y-2)^{2}-1 \text {. }
$$

Since the parabola passes through $A(3,0)$, substituting gives $a=1$.
At this time, the equation of the new parabola is
$$
x=(y-2)^{2}-1=y^{2}-4 y+3 \text {. }
$$
(2) If the original parabola is rotated $90^{\circ}$ counterclockwise around $A(3,0)$, using the same method, the equation of the new parabola is
$$
x=-(y+2)^{2}+7=-y^{2}-4 y+3 \text {. }
$$

Combining (1) and (2), the equation of the new parabola is
$$
x=y^{2}-4 y+3 \text { or } x=-y^{2}-4 y+3 \text {. }
$$
(Li Ming, Wuhu County No. 3 Middle School, Anhui, 233300)
informal_statement: Three, (25 points) Find the equation of the parabola obtained by rotating the parabola $y=x^{2}-2 x-3$ around point $A(3,0)$ by $90^{\circ}$ (Note: $x$ is a quadratic function of $y$).
informal_proof:
Let $y$ be an arbitrary real number. We want to prove that there exists a real number $x$ such that either $x = y^2 - 4y + 3$ or $x = -y^2 - 4y + 3$.

To prove this existential statement, we will construct such an $x$. Let us define $x$ to be $y^2 - 4y + 3$.

Now, we must show that this choice of $x$ satisfies the condition $x = y^2 - 4y + 3 \lor x = -y^2 - 4y + 3$. We can prove this disjunction by proving its first part, which is the statement $x = y^2 - 4y + 3$.

By our definition of $x$, this equality holds.

Since we have found an appropriate value of $x$ for any given $y$, the claim is established.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Three, (25 points) Find the equation of the parabola obtained by rotating the parabola $y=x^{2}-2 x-3$ around point $A(3,0)$ by $90^{\circ}$ (Note: $x$ is a quadratic function of $y$). -/
theorem algebra_319846 {f g : ℝ → ℝ} (hf : f = fun x => x^2 - 2 * x - 3) :
    ∀ y, ∃ x, x = y^2 - 4 * y + 3 ∨ x = -y^2 - 4 * y + 3 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_319846 {f g : ℝ → ℝ} (hf : f = fun x => x^2 - 2 * x - 3) :
    ∀ y, ∃ x, x = y^2 - 4 * y + 3 ∨ x = -y^2 - 4 * y + 3 := by
  intro y
  refine ⟨y^2 - 4 * y + 3, Or.inl rfl⟩

Solution. Let's form the characteristic equation and find its roots: $k^{2}-4 k+13=0 ; k_{1}=2+3 i, k_{2}=2-3 i$.

Write down the general solution of the equation:

y=e^{2 x}\left(C_{1} \cos 3 x+C_{2} \sin 3 x\right)
$$
informal_statement: 149. Find the general solution of the equation $y^{\prime \prime}-4 y^{\prime}+13 y=0$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 149. Find the general solution of the equation $y^{\prime \prime}-4 y^{\prime}+13 y=0$. -/
theorem calculus_157478 (y : ℝ → ℝ) (hy : Differentiable ℝ y) (h : ∀ x, iteratedDeriv 2 y x - 4 * deriv y x + 13 * y x = 0) :
    ∃ c1 c2, ∀ x, y x = c1 * Real.exp (2 * x) * Real.cos (3 * x) + c2 * Real.exp (2 * x) * Real.sin (3 * x) := by

informal_statement:
Given that the angle between vectors $\overrightarrow{a}$ and $\overrightarrow{b}$ is $60{}^\circ $, and $\left| \overrightarrow{a} \right|=1$, $\left| \overrightarrow{a}-2\overrightarrow{b} \right|=\sqrt{13}$, then $\left| \overrightarrow{b} \right|=$（   ）．

A:$\sqrt{2}$

B:$\frac{3}{2}$

C:$2\sqrt{2}$

D:$2$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Given that the angle between vectors $\overrightarrow{a}$ and $\overrightarrow{b}$ is $60{}^\circ $, and $\left| \overrightarrow{a} \right|=1$, $\left| \overrightarrow{a}-2\overrightarrow{b} \right|=\sqrt{13}$, then $\left| \overrightarrow{b} \right|=$（   ）．

A:$\sqrt{2}$

B:$\frac{3}{2}$

C:$2\sqrt{2}$

D:$2$ -/
theorem algebra_12648 (a b : ℝ × ℝ) (h₀ : Real.sqrt (a.1^2 + a.2^2) = 1)
    (h₁ : Real.sqrt ((a.1 - 2 * b.1)^2 + (a.2 - 2 * b.2)^2) = Real.sqrt 13)
    (h₂ : Real.arccos ((a.1 * b.1 + a.2 * b.2) / (Real.sqrt (a.1^2 + a.2^2) * Real.sqrt (b.1^2 + b.2^2))) = Real.pi / 3) :
    Real.sqrt (b.1^2 + b.2^2) = 2 := by

soln_description:
Answer: $\quad m=33, n=61$.

The solution follows from the prime factorization $2013=3 \cdot 11 \cdot 61$ and a small enumeration of the divisors of 2013; there are 8 in total, and the "candidates" for the role of the number $m$ are the smaller divisors, namely the four numbers $1,3,11,33$, and among them, only $m=33$ satisfies the condition $m<n<2m$ with $n=61$.
informal_statement: 7.1. Find two natural numbers $m$ and $n$, given that $m<n<2m$ and $mn=2013$.
informal_proof:
We are given that `m` and `n` are natural numbers satisfying three conditions:
1. `m < n`
2. `n < 2m`
3. `m * n = 2013`

Our goal is to prove that `m = 33` and `n = 61`.

First, we establish some basic bounds. We can show that `m ≤ 2013`. Assume for contradiction that `m > 2013`. Since `m` and `n` are natural numbers and `m < n`, it must be that `n ≥ 1`. Multiplying the inequality `m > 2013` by `n` gives `m * n > 2013 * n ≥ 2013 * 1 = 2013`. This contradicts our given condition that `m * n = 2013`. Thus, the assumption `m > 2013` is false, and we must have `m ≤ 2013`. A similar argument shows that `n ≤ 2013`.

From the condition `m * n = 2013`, we know that `m` must be a divisor of 2013. We can further constrain the possible values of `m`. Since `m < n`, we can multiply both sides by `m` (which is positive, as `m*n=2013`) to get `m^2 < m * n`. Substituting the given equality, we have `m^2 < 2013`. This implies that `m < √2013`. Since `44^2 = 1936` and `45^2 = 2025`, we know that `√2013` is between 44 and 45. Therefore, `m` must be a natural number such that `m ≤ 44`.

The prime factorization of 2013 is `3 × 11 × 61`. The divisors of 2013 are 1, 3, 11, 33, 61, 183, 671, and 2013.
Considering our derived constraint `m ≤ 44`, the only possible values for `m` are 1, 3, 11, and 33. We proceed by examining each of these cases.

**Case 1: `m = 1`**
If `m = 1`, then from `m * n = 2013` we get `n = 2013`. We check this against the condition `n < 2m`. This gives `2013 < 2 * 1`, or `2013 < 2`, which is false. Thus, `m` cannot be 1.

**Case 2: `m = 3`**
If `m = 3`, then `n = 2013 / 3 = 671`. We check the condition `n < 2m`. This gives `671 < 2 * 3`, or `671 < 6`, which is false. Thus, `m` cannot be 3.

**Case 3: `m = 11`**
If `m = 11`, then `n = 2013 / 11 = 183`. We check the condition `n < 2m`. This gives `183 < 2 * 11`, or `183 < 22`, which is false. Thus, `m` cannot be 11.

**Case 4: `m = 33`**
If `m = 33`, then `n = 2013 / 33 = 61`. We check both inequality conditions:
- `m < n` becomes `33 < 61`, which is true.
- `n < 2m` becomes `61 < 2 * 33`, or `61 < 66`, which is true.
All three initial conditions are satisfied for this pair of values.

Since we have exhausted all possible values for `m`, we conclude that the only solution is `m = 33` and `n = 61`.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 7.1. Find two natural numbers $m$ and $n$, given that $m<n<2m$ and $mn=2013$. -/
theorem number_theory_235753 {m n : ℕ} (hm : m < n) (hn : n < 2 * m) (hmn : m * n = 2013) :
    m = 33 ∧ n = 61 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_235753 {m n : ℕ} (hm : m < n) (hn : n < 2 * m) (hmn : m * n = 2013) :
    m = 33 ∧ n = 61 := by
  have h1 : m ≤ 2013 := by
    by_contra h
    push_neg at h
    have h2 : m * n > 2013 := by
      nlinarith [h, show n ≥ 1 by nlinarith]
    nlinarith
  have h2 : n ≤ 2013 := by
    by_contra h
    push_neg at h
    have h3 : m * n > 2013 := by
      nlinarith [h, show m ≥ 1 by nlinarith]
    nlinarith
  interval_cases m <;> omega

soln_description:
Two, first prove a lemma.
Lemma Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{n}$ and $b_{1}, b_{2}, \cdots, b_{n}$ be two sets of positive numbers, and
$$
b_{1}>b_{2}>\cdots>b_{n} .
$$

If for any positive integer $k$ we have
$$
b_{1}+b_{2}+\cdots+b_{k} \leqslant a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{k} \text {, }
$$
$$
\text { then } b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{k}^{2} \leqslant a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{k}^{2} \text {. }
$$

Proof Define $b_{n+1}=0$. From (1) and (2) we get
$$
\begin{array}{l}
{\left[\sum_{k=1}^{n}\left(b_{k}-b_{k+1}\right)\right]\left(\sum_{i=1}^{k} b_{i}\right)} \\
\leqslant\left[\sum_{k=1}^{n}\left(b_{k}-b_{k+1}\right)\right]\left(\sum_{i=1}^{k} a_{i}\right) .
\end{array}
$$

By changing the order of summation, we get
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}\right)\left[\sum_{k=i}^{n}\left(b_{k}-b_{k+1}\right)\right] \\
\leqslant\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}\right)\left[\sum_{k=i}^{n}\left(b_{k}-b_{k+1}\right)\right] \\
\Rightarrow \sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2} \leqslant \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i} \\
\Rightarrow\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right)^{2} \leqslant\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} b_{i}\right)^{2} \\
\quad \leqslant\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}\right)\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2}\right) \\
\Rightarrow \sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2} \leqslant \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2} .
\end{array}
$$

The lemma is proved.
Take $b_{k}=\sqrt{k}-\sqrt{k-1}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{k}+\sqrt{k-1}}$.
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { Then } \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}^{2} \geqslant \sum_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}^{2}=\sum\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{k}+\sqrt{k-1}}\right)^{2} \\
>\sum\left(\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{k}}\right)^{2}=\sum \frac{1}{4 k} .
\end{array}
$$
informal_statement:
Sure, here is the translated text:

```
II. (40 points) Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots$ be a sequence of positive real numbers, and for all positive integers $n \geqslant 1$, we have
$$
a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} \geqslant \sqrt{n} \text {. }
$$

Prove: For all positive integers $n \geqslant 1$, we have
$$
a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}>\frac{1}{4}\left(1+\frac{1}{2}+\cdots+\frac{1}{n}\right) .
$$
```
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- II. (40 points) Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots$ be a sequence of positive real numbers, and for all positive integers $n \geqslant 1$,
$$
a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} \geqslant \sqrt{n} \text {. }
$$

Prove: For all positive integers $n \geqslant 1$,
$$
a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}>\frac{1}{4}\left(1+\frac{1}{2}+\cdots+\frac{1}{n}\right) .
$$ -/
theorem inequalities_325045 (a : ℕ → ℝ) (ha : ∀ n, 0 < a n)
    (h : ∀ n, ∑ i in Finset.Icc 1 n, a i ≥ sqrt n) :
    ∀ n, 1 ≤ n → ∑ i in Finset.Icc 1 n, (a i)^2 > 1 / 4 * ∑ i in Finset.Icc 1 n, 1 / i := by

informal_statement: 4. (8 points) For a natural number $N$, if at least five of the nine natural numbers from $1$ to $9$ can divide $N$, then $N$ is called a "five-smooth number". The smallest "five-smooth number" greater than 2000 is $\qquad$ .
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

def is_five_smooth (N : ℕ) : Prop :=
  {k | k ∈ Finset.Icc 1 9 ∧ N % k = 0}.ncard ≥ 5

/- 4. (8 points) For a natural number $N$, if at least five of the nine natural numbers from $1$ to $9$ can divide $N$, then $N$ is called a "five-smooth number". The smallest "five-smooth number" greater than 2000 is $\qquad$ . -/
theorem number_theory_186191 :
    IsLeast {N | 2000 < N ∧ is_five_smooth N} 2004 := by

soln_description:
Since $\left(2^{a}\right)\left(2^{b}\right)=64$, then $2^{a+b}=64$, using an exponent law.

Since $64=2^{6}$, then $2^{a+b}=2^{6}$ and so $a+b=6$.

Therefore, the average of $a$ and $b$ is $\frac{1}{2}(a+b)=3$.

ANSWER: (D)
informal_statement:
If $\left(2^{a}\right)\left(2^{b}\right)=64$, then the mean (average) of $a$ and $b$ is
(A) 12
(B) $\frac{5}{2}$
(C) $\frac{3}{2}$
(D) 3
(E) 8

Part B: Each correct answer is worth 6.
informal_proof:
Let $a$ and $b$ be natural numbers. We are given the equation $\left(2^{a}\right)\left(2^{b}\right)=64$.

Our goal is to find the value of $\frac{a+b}{2}$.

First, we simplify the left side of the given equation using the law of exponents, which states that $x^m \cdot x^n = x^{m+n}$. Applying this rule, we have:
$2^a \cdot 2^b = 2^{a+b}$.

Substituting this back into the original equation, we get:
$2^{a+b} = 64$.

Next, we express the number 64 as a power of 2. Since $64 = 2^6$, we can rewrite the equation as:
$2^{a+b} = 2^6$.

Because the function $f(n) = 2^n$ is injective for natural numbers $n$, if $2^x = 2^y$, it must be that $x = y$. Therefore, we can equate the exponents in our equation to find:
$a+b = 6$.

Finally, we compute the desired expression by substituting the value we found for $a+b$:
$\frac{a+b}{2} = \frac{6}{2} = 3$.

Thus, the average of $a$ and $b$ is 3.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- If $\left(2^{a}\right)\left(2^{b}\right)=64$, then the mean (average) of $a$ and $b$ is
(A) 12
(B) $\frac{5}{2}$
(C) $\frac{3}{2}$
(D) 3
(E) 8

Part B: Each correct answer is worth 6. -/
theorem algebra_274245 {a b : ℕ} (h : (2^a) * (2^b) = 64) : (a + b) / 2 = 3 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_274245 {a b : ℕ} (h : (2^a) * (2^b) = 64) : (a + b) / 2 = 3 := by
  have h1 : 2 ^ a * 2 ^ b = 2 ^ (a + b) := by
    rw [← pow_add]
    all_goals norm_num
  have h2 : 2 ^ (a + b) = 64 := by
    linarith [h, h1]
  have h3 : a + b = 6 := by
    have h4 : 2 ^ (a + b) = 2 ^ 6 := by
      rw [h2]
      all_goals norm_num
    have h5 : a + b = 6 := by
      exact Nat.pow_right_injective (by norm_num) h4
    exact h5
  calc
    (a + b) / 2 = 6 / 2 := by rw [show a + b = 6 by linarith [h3]]
    _ = 3 := by norm_num

soln_description:
Solution. If in the equation we replace $\sqrt{8-\sqrt{3}}$ with $\frac{1}{\sqrt{3+\sqrt{8}}}$, we will get an equivalent equation

$$
(\sqrt{3+\sqrt{8}})^{2 x}-6(\sqrt{3+\sqrt{8}})^{x}+1=0
$$

If we let $(\sqrt{3+\sqrt{8}})^{x}=y$, we will get the following quadratic equation

$$
y^{2}-6 y+1=0
$$

whose solutions are $y=3+2 \sqrt{2}$ and $y=3-2 \sqrt{2}$. From $(\sqrt{3+\sqrt{8}})^{x}=3+2 \sqrt{2}$, we get $x=2$, and from $(\sqrt{3+\sqrt{8}})^{x}=\frac{1}{3+2 \sqrt{2}}=(3+2 \sqrt{2})^{-1}$, we get $x=-2$.

Therefore, the equation has two solutions $x_{1}=2$ and $x_{2}=-2$.
informal_statement:
1. Solve the equation

$$
(\sqrt{3-\sqrt{8}})^{x}+(\sqrt{3+\sqrt{8}})^{x}=6
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1. Solve the equation

$$
(\sqrt{3-\sqrt{8}})^{x}+(\sqrt{3+\sqrt{8}})^{x}=6
$$ -/
theorem algebra_222096 (x : ℝ) :
    (Real.sqrt (3 - Real.sqrt 8))^x + (Real.sqrt (3 + Real.sqrt 8))^x = 6 ↔ x = 2 ∨ x = -2 := by

soln_description:
(-2) By the median length formula $P K=\frac{1}{2} \sqrt{2\left(A K^{2}+B K^{2}\right)-A B^{2}}$, let the inradius of $\triangle A B C$ be $r$, then $P K=\frac{r}{\sin \frac{C}{2}}$, thus
$$2\left(A K^{2}+B K^{2}\right)=A B^{2}+4 P K^{2}=c^{2}+r^{2}+\frac{1}{4}(a+b-c)^{2}$$

Similarly,
$$\begin{array}{l}
2\left(B K^{2}+C K^{2}\right)=B C^{2}+4 M K^{2}=a^{2}+r^{2}+\frac{1}{4}(b+c-a)^{2} \\
2\left(A K^{2}+B K^{2}\right)=C A^{2}+4 N K^{2}=b^{2}+r^{2}+\frac{1}{4}(c+a-b)^{2}
\end{array}$$

Adding them up, we get
$$\begin{array}{l}
3 r^{2}+\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)+\frac{1}{4}(a+b-c)^{2}+\frac{1}{4}(b+c-a)^{2}+\frac{1}{4}(c+a-b)^{2}= \\
4\left(A K^{2}+B K^{2}+C K^{2}\right)
\end{array}$$

If the conclusion does not hold, then $A K<\frac{a}{\sqrt{3}}, B K<\frac{b}{\sqrt{3}}, C K<\frac{c}{\sqrt{3}}$, substituting into the above equation, we have
$$\begin{array}{c}
5\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)+36 r^{2}<6(a b+b c+c a) \\
8\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}\right)+36 r^{2}<3(a+b+c)^{2}
\end{array}$$

If this inequality does not hold, then the conclusion is proven. Since $a=r\left(\cot \frac{B}{2}+\cot \frac{C}{2}\right), b=$ $r\left(\cot \frac{C}{2}+\cot \frac{A}{2}\right), c=r\left(\cot \frac{A}{2}+\cot \frac{B}{2}\right)$, therefore, we only need to prove
$$\begin{array}{l}
8\left(\left(\cot \frac{B}{2}+\cot \frac{C}{2}\right)^{2}+\left(\cot \frac{C}{2}+\cot \frac{A}{2}\right)+\left(\cot \frac{A}{2}+\cot \frac{B}{2}\right)^{2}\right)+36< \\
12\left(\cot \frac{A}{2}+\cot \frac{B}{2}+\cot \frac{C}{2}\right)^{2}
\end{array}$$

The above equation can be simplified to
$$\begin{array}{l}
\left(\cot ^{2} \frac{A}{2}+\cot ^{2} \frac{B}{2}+\cot ^{2} \frac{C}{2}\right)+9 \geqslant \\
2\left(\cot \frac{A}{2} \cot \frac{B}{2}+\cot \frac{B}{2} \cot \frac{C}{2}+\cot \frac{C}{2} \cot \frac{A}{2}\right) \Leftrightarrow \\
\left(\cot \frac{A}{2}+\cot \frac{B}{2}+\cot \frac{C}{2}\right)^{2}+94\left(\cot \frac{A}{2} \cot \frac{B}{2}+\cot \frac{B}{2} \cot \frac{C}{2}+\cot \frac{C}{2} \cot \frac{A}{2}\right)
\end{array}$$

See the previous problem for the following.
informal_statement: (2) $\frac{K A}{B C}, \frac{K B}{C A}, \frac{K C}{A B}$ among these, at least one is not less than $\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}$. (2003 Vietnam National Team Selection Exam Problem)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- (2) $\frac{K A}{B C}, \frac{K B}{C A}, \frac{K C}{A B}$ among these, at least one is not less than $\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}$. (2003 Vietnam National Team Selection Exam Problem) -/
theorem inequalities_600556 (K A B C : ℝ) (hA : 0 < A) (hB : 0 < B) (hC : 0 < C)
    (hK : K ≠ 0) :
    1 / sqrt 3 ≤ K * A / (B * C) ∨ 1 / sqrt 3 ≤ K * B / (C * A) ∨
    1 / sqrt 3 ≤ K * C / (A * B) := by

soln_description: A little experimentation suggests that such pairs are relatively rare. The smallest b seems to be 57, with 25.26 dividing 57 2 + 1 (and a more extensive search than one would want to carry out by hand suggest there are no other b under 200). Suppose d 2 divides c 2 + 1. Put b = c(d 2 + 1) + d 3 . Then b 2 + 1 = c 2 (d 2 + 1) 2 + 2cd 3 (d 2 + 1) + d 6 + 1. Since d 6 + 1 = (d 2 + 1)(d 4 - d 2 + 1), it is clear that b 2 + 1 is divisible by d 2 + 1. Since c 2 + 1 is divisible by d 2 , b 2 + 1 is also divisible by d 2 . So if we can find c and d, then we can take a = d 2 and b = c(d 2 + 1) + d 3 . That is more promising. We can specialise down to c 2 + 1 = 2d 2 . We may remember that solutions to the Pell equation (and its variants) generate further solutions as simple linear combinations. So starting with (m, n) satisfying m 2 + 1 = 2n 2 we get M 2 + 1 = 2N 2 by taking M = 3m + 4n, N = 2m + 3n. So starting with the solution (7, 5) we get (41, 29), (239, 169), ... . That gives an increasing sequence (c, d) and hence an increasing sequence (a, b). 40th IMO shortlist 1999 © John Scholes jscholes@kalva.demon.co.uk 10 Oct 2002
informal_statement: 40th IMO 1999 shortlist Problem N3 Show that there exist two strictly increasing sequences a 1 , a 2 , a 3 , ... and b 1 , b 2 , b 3 , ... such that a n (a n + 1) divides b n 2 + 1 for each n.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib.Tactic

/- 40th IMO 1999 shortlist Problem N3 Show that there exist two strictly increasing sequences a 1 , a 2 , a 3 , ... and b 1 , b 2 , b 3 , ... such that a n (a n + 1) divides b n 2 + 1 for each n. -/
theorem number_theory_121970 : ∃ a b : ℕ → ℤ,
    StrictMono a ∧
    StrictMono b ∧
    ∀ n : ℕ, 0 < a n ∧ 0 < b n ∧
    a n * (a n + 1) ∣ b n ^ 2 + 1 :=

informal_statement:
7. Given the sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ satisfies
$$
a_{n}=\left[(2+\sqrt{5})^{n}+\frac{1}{2^{n}}\right]\left(n \in \mathbf{Z}_{+}\right) \text {, }
$$

where $[x]$ denotes the greatest integer not exceeding the real number $x$. Let $C$ be a real number such that for any positive integer $n$, we have
$$
\sum_{k=1}^{n} \frac{1}{a_{k} a_{k+2}} \leqslant C \text {. }
$$

Then the minimum value of $C$ is $\qquad$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- 7. Given the sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ satisfies
$$
a_{n}=\left[(2+\sqrt{5})^{n}+\frac{1}{2^{n}}\right]\left(n \in \mathbf{Z}_{+}\right) \text {, }
$$

where $[x]$ denotes the greatest integer not exceeding the real number $x$. Let $C$ be a real number such that for any positive integer $n$, we have
$$
\sum_{k=1}^{n} \frac{1}{a_{k} a_{k+2}} \leqslant C \text {. }
$$

Then the minimum value of $C$ is $\qquad$ -/
theorem algebra_130061 (a : ℕ → ℝ)
    (ha : ∀ n, a n = ⌊(2 + sqrt 5)^n + 1 / 2^n⌋) :
    IsLeast {C | ∀ n, ∑ k in Finset.Icc 1 n, 1 / (a k * a (k + 2)) ≤ C} (1 / 288) := by

informal_statement: Consider the sequence defined by $a_n = \sin(n^n)$. Prove that this sequence is divergent.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Topology Filter Real Complex TopologicalSpace Finset
open scoped BigOperators

/- Consider the sequence defined by $a_n = \sin(n^n)$. Prove that this sequence is divergent. -/
theorem calculus_1261 (a : ℕ → ℝ) (ha : ∀ n, a n = Real.sin (n ^ n)) :
  ¬ ∃ L, Tendsto a atTop (𝓝 L) :=

informal_statement: Prove that if $a$ and $b$ are odd integers, then $8 \mid a^2 - b^2$.
informal_proof:
Let $a$ and $b$ be odd integers. We want to show that $8$ divides $a^2 - b^2$. We will prove this by showing that $a^2 - b^2$ is congruent to $0$ modulo $8$.

First, let's consider the possible remainders of an odd integer when divided by $8$. Since $a$ is odd, by definition, there exists an integer $k$ such that $a = 2k + 1$. The possible remainders of $a$ modulo $8$ are $1, 3, 5,$ and $7$. Any other remainder would imply $a$ is even.

Next, we will show that the square of any odd integer is congruent to $1$ modulo $8$. We do this by examining the square of each possible remainder:
- If $a \equiv 1 \pmod{8}$, then $a^2 \equiv 1^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{8}$.
- If $a \equiv 3 \pmod{8}$, then $a^2 \equiv 3^2 \equiv 9 \equiv 1 \pmod{8}$.
- If $a \equiv 5 \pmod{8}$, then $a^2 \equiv 5^2 \equiv 25 \equiv 1 \pmod{8}$ (since $25 = 3 \times 8 + 1$).
- If $a \equiv 7 \pmod{8}$, then $a^2 \equiv 7^2 \equiv 49 \equiv 1 \pmod{8}$ (since $49 = 6 \times 8 + 1$).

In all cases, if $a$ is an odd integer, we have $a^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{8}$.

Since both $a$ and $b$ are given to be odd integers, we can apply this result to both:
1. $a^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{8}$
2. $b^2 \equiv 1 \pmod{8}$

Now, we can consider the difference $a^2 - b^2$ modulo $8$:
$$ a^2 - b^2 \equiv 1 - 1 \pmod{8} $$
$$ a^2 - b^2 \equiv 0 \pmod{8} $$

By the definition of congruence, this means that $8$ divides $a^2 - b^2$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Prove that if $a$ and $b$ are odd integers, then $8 \mid a^2 - b^2$. -/
theorem number_theory_5322 (a b : ℤ) (ha : Odd a) (hb : Odd b) :
  8 ∣ a^2 - b^2 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_5322 (a b : ℤ) (ha : Odd a) (hb : Odd b) :
  8 ∣ a^2 - b^2 := by 
  have h1 : a % 8 = 1 ∨ a % 8 = 3 ∨ a % 8 = 5 ∨ a % 8 = 7 := by 
    rcases ha with ⟨k, hk⟩ 
    omega 
  have h2 : b % 8 = 1 ∨ b % 8 = 3 ∨ b % 8 = 5 ∨ b % 8 = 7 := by 
    rcases hb with ⟨k, hk⟩ 
    omega 
  have h3 : a^2 % 8 = 1 := by 
    rcases h1 with (h1 | h1 | h1 | h1)
    · simp [pow_two, Int.mul_emod, h1, Int.add_emod, Int.mul_emod]
    · simp [pow_two, Int.mul_emod, h1, Int.add_emod, Int.mul_emod]
    · simp [pow_two, Int.mul_emod, h1, Int.add_emod, Int.mul_emod]
    · simp [pow_two, Int.mul_emod, h1, Int.add_emod, Int.mul_emod]
  have h4 : b^2 % 8 = 1 := by 
    rcases h2 with (h2 | h2 | h2 | h2)
    · simp [pow_two, Int.mul_emod, h2, Int.add_emod, Int.mul_emod]
    · simp [pow_two, Int.mul_emod, h2, Int.add_emod, Int.mul_emod]
    · simp [pow_two, Int.mul_emod, h2, Int.add_emod, Int.mul_emod]
    · simp [pow_two, Int.mul_emod, h2, Int.add_emod, Int.mul_emod]
  have h5 : (a^2 - b^2) % 8 = 0 := by 
    omega 
  exact Int.dvd_of_emod_eq_zero h5

soln_description:
2. Let $(x, y)$ be its positive integer solution, then $x, y$ have the same parity, hence, $\frac{x-y}{2} \cdot \frac{x+y}{2}=$ $5^{2} \times 30^{2 n}=2^{2 n} \times 3^{2 n} \times 5^{2 n+2}$.

We can obtain
$$a_{n}=\frac{1}{2}\left((2 n+1)^{2}(2 n+3)-1\right)=(n+1)\left(4 n^{2}+6 n+1\right)$$
(because $\frac{x-y}{2}<\frac{x+y}{2}$, they are both positive divisors of $2^{2 n} \times 3^{2 n} \times 5^{2 n+2}$.) Note that,
$$\begin{aligned}
\left(n+1,4 n^{2}+6 n+1\right) & =(n+1,(4 n+2)(n+1)-1) \\
& =(n+1,-1)=1,
\end{aligned}$$

Also, $(2 n+1)^{2}<4 n^{2}+6 n+1<(2 n+2)^{2}$, which means $4 n^{2}+6 n+1$ is not a perfect square. Therefore, $a_{n}$ is not a perfect square.
informal_statement: 2. Let $n \in \mathbf{N}^{*}, a_{n}$ be the number of positive integer solutions $(x, y)$ to the indeterminate equation $x^{2}-y^{2}=10^{2} \cdot 30^{2 n}$. Prove: $a_{n}$ is not a perfect square.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 2. Let $n \in \mathbf{N}^{*}, a_{n}$ be the number of positive integer solutions $(x, y)$ to the indeterminate equation $x^{2}-y^{2}=10^{2} \cdot 30^{2 n}$. Prove: $a_{n}$ is not a perfect square. -/
theorem number_theory_7482 (n : ℕ) (hn : n > 0) :
    ¬ ∃ m, m^2 = (Nat.card {p : ℕ × ℕ | p.1 > 0 ∧ p.2 > 0 ∧ p.1^2 - p.2^2 = 10^2 * 30^(2 * n)}) := by

soln_description:
To prove that every selection of \(1325\) integers from \(M = \{1, 2, \ldots, 1987\}\) must contain some three numbers \(\{a, b, c\}\) which are pairwise relatively prime, we can use the following steps:

1. **Identify the Primes and Multiples**:
   - Let \(p_1, p_2, \ldots, p_n\) be the sequence of primes less than or equal to \(1987\).
   - We need to determine the largest subset of \(M\) that does not contain \(k+1\) pairwise relatively prime elements.

2. **Use the Principle of Inclusion-Exclusion (PIE)**:
   - To find the largest subset of \(M\) that does not contain \(k+1\) pairwise relatively prime elements, we consider the subset containing all multiples of \(p_1, p_2, \ldots, p_k\).
   - The number of multiples of a prime \(p_i\) in \(M\) is \(\left\lfloor \frac{1987}{p_i} \right\rfloor\).

3. **Calculate the Size of the Subset**:
   - Using PIE, we calculate the size of the subset containing all multiples of \(p_1, p_2, \ldots, p_k\).
   - For \(k = 2\), we need to find the number of integers in \(M\) that are multiples of \(2\) or \(3\).

4. **Apply PIE for \(k = 2\)**:
   - Let \(A\) be the set of multiples of \(2\) in \(M\).
   - Let \(B\) be the set of multiples of \(3\) in \(M\).
   - The size of \(A\) is \(\left\lfloor \frac{1987}{2} \right\rfloor = 993\).
   - The size of \(B\) is \(\left\lfloor \frac{1987}{3} \right\rfloor = 662\).
   - The size of \(A \cap B\) (multiples of \(6\)) is \(\left\lfloor \frac{1987}{6} \right\rfloor = 331\).

5. **Calculate the Total Size**:
   - Using PIE, the size of the subset containing all multiples of \(2\) or \(3\) is:
     \[
     |A \cup B| = |A| + |B| - |A \cap B| = 993 + 662 - 331 = 1324
     \]

6. **Conclusion**:
   - The largest subset of \(M\) that does not contain \(3\) pairwise relatively prime elements has size \(1324\).
   - Therefore, if we select \(1325\) integers from \(M\), there must be some three numbers \(\{a, b, c\}\) which are pairwise relatively prime.

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement: Prove that every selection of $1325$ integers from $M=\{1, 2, \cdots, 1987 \}$ must contain some three numbers $\{a, b, c\}$ which are pairwise relatively prime, but that it can be avoided if only $1324$ integers are selected.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Prove that every selection of $1325$ integers from $M=\{1, 2, \cdots, 1987 \}$ must contain some three numbers $\{a, b, c\}$ which are pairwise relatively prime, but that it can be avoided if only $1324$ integers are selected. -/
theorem number_theory_74295 (M : Finset ℕ) (hM : M = Finset.Icc 1 1987) :
    (∀ S : Finset ℕ, S ⊆ M ∧ S.card = 1325 →
      ∃ a ∈ S, ∃ b ∈ S, ∃ c ∈ S, a ≠ b ∧ a ≠ c ∧ b ≠ c ∧ Nat.Coprime a b ∧ Nat.Coprime a c ∧ Nat.Coprime b c) ∧
    (∃ S : Finset ℕ, S ⊆ M ∧ S.card = 1324 ∧ ¬∃ a ∈ S, ∃ b ∈ S, ∃ c ∈ S, a ≠ b ∧ a ≠ c ∧ b ≠ c ∧ Nat.Coprime a b ∧ Nat.Coprime a c ∧ Nat.Coprime b c) := by

soln_description:
2. Answer: 998412.

Solution. The largest four-digit number divisible by 13 is 9997. Among the numbers from 99970 to 99979, there is a number 99977 divisible by 17, but among the numbers from 999770 to 999779, there is no number divisible by 19. However, for the next number 9984, which is divisible by 13, the number 99841 is divisible by 17, and the number 998412 is divisible by 19.

Criteria. Correct and justified answer - 7 points; correct answer, but not proven to be the largest - 4 points; incorrect answer - 0 points.
informal_statement: 2. A six-digit number $A$ is divisible by 19. The number obtained by removing its last digit is divisible by 17, and the number obtained by removing the last two digits of $A$ is divisible by 13. Find the largest $A$ that satisfies these conditions.
informal_proof:
Let S be the set of six-digit natural numbers `A` such that `A` is divisible by 19, the number obtained by removing its last digit (`A` divided by 10) is divisible by 17, and the number obtained by removing its last two digits (`A` divided by 100) is divisible by 13. We want to show that 998412 is the largest number in this set.

To prove this, we must establish two facts:
1.  998412 is an element of the set S.
2.  For any element `A` in S, `A ≤ 998412`.

**Part 1: Verifying that 998412 is in the set S.**
We check that 998412 satisfies all the required conditions for membership in S:
*   **It is a six-digit number:** 998412 lies in the interval [100000, 999999], as `100000 ≤ 998412` and `998412 ≤ 999999`.
*   **Divisibility by 19:** `998412 = 19 × 52548`, so 19 divides 998412.
*   **Divisibility of `A/10` by 17:** Removing the last digit of 998412 gives 99841. We check that `99841 = 17 × 5873`, so 17 divides 99841.
*   **Divisibility of `A/100` by 13:** Removing the last two digits of 998412 gives 9984. We check that `9984 = 13 × 768`, so 13 divides 9984.

Since all four conditions are met, 998412 is an element of the set S.

**Part 2: Verifying that 998412 is the greatest element.**
Let `A` be an arbitrary element of S. By definition of S, we know `A` is a six-digit number (`100000 ≤ A ≤ 999999`) and satisfies the three divisibility conditions. We will prove by contradiction that `A ≤ 998412`.

Assume, for the sake of contradiction, that `A > 998412`.
From the six-digit number condition, we have `A ≤ 999999`. Combining this with our assumption, `A` must lie in the integer interval `[998413, 999999]`.

We now perform a case analysis for every integer value of `A` in this range. For each such `A`, we check if it satisfies the three divisibility properties required for membership in S:
1. `19 ∣ A`
2. `17 ∣ (A / 10)`
3. `13 ∣ (A / 100)`

A systematic check of all integers from 998413 to 999999 reveals that no single integer in this range satisfies all three divisibility conditions simultaneously. For any choice of `A` in this range, at least one of the conditions fails. This contradicts our premise that `A` is an element of S.

Since our assumption that `A > 998412` leads to a contradiction for every possible case, the assumption must be false. Therefore, for any `A` in S, it must be that `A ≤ 998412`.

Having shown that 998412 is in the set S and that it is an upper bound for all elements in S, we conclude that 998412 is the largest number that satisfies the given conditions.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 2. A six-digit number $A$ is divisible by 19. The number obtained by removing its last digit is divisible by 17, and the number obtained by removing the last two digits of $A$ is divisible by 13. Find the largest $A$ that satisfies these conditions. -/
theorem number_theory_155109 :
    IsGreatest {A : ℕ | A ∈ Finset.Icc 100000 999999 ∧ 19 ∣ A ∧ 17 ∣ (A / 10) ∧ 13 ∣ (A / 100)} 998412 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_155109 :
    IsGreatest {A : ℕ | A ∈ Finset.Icc 100000 999999 ∧ 19 ∣ A ∧ 17 ∣ (A / 10) ∧ 13 ∣ (A / 100)} 998412 := by
  constructor
  · -- Show that 998412 is in the set
    constructor
    · norm_num [Finset.mem_Icc]
    constructor
    · norm_num
    constructor
    · norm_num
    · norm_num
  · -- Show that 998412 is greatest in the set
    intro A h
    rcases h with ⟨hA, h19, h17, h13⟩
    rw [Finset.mem_Icc] at hA
    rcases hA with ⟨hA1, hA2⟩
    by_contra h'
    push_neg at h'
    interval_cases A <;> norm_num at h19 h17 h13 <;> all_goals omega

informal_statement: Let $a, b, c$ be distinct positive integers and let $r, s, t$ be positive integers such that $ab + 1 = r^2$, $ac + 1 = s^2$, and $bc + 1 = t^2$. Prove that it is not possible for all three fractions $\frac{rt}{s}$, $\frac{rs}{t}$, and $\frac{st}{r}$ to be integers.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib
import Aesop

open BigOperators Real Nat Topology Rat

/- Let $a, b, c$ be distinct positive integers and let $r, s, t$ be positive integers such that $ab + 1 = r^2$, $ac + 1 = s^2$, and $bc + 1 = t^2$. Prove that it is not possible for all three fractions $\frac{rt}{s}$, $\frac{rs}{t}$, and $\frac{st}{r}$ to be integers. -/
theorem number_theory_9012
  (a b c r s t : ℕ)
  (habc : a > 0 ∧ b > 0 ∧ c > 0 ∧ a ≠ b ∧ a ≠ c ∧ b ≠ c)
  (h1 : r > 0)
  (h2 : s > 0)
  (h3 : t > 0)
  (h4 : a * b + 1 = r^2)
  (h5 : a * c + 1 = s^2)
  (h6 : b * c + 1 = t^2) :
  ¬(∃ k l m : ℕ, 0 < k ∧ 0 < l ∧ 0 < m ∧ k = (r * t : ℚ) / s ∧ l = (r * s : ℚ) / t ∧ m = (s * t : ℚ) / r) := by

soln_description: 12. $2 f(0)=c, f(1)=a-b+c, f(-1)=a-b+c \cdot a=\frac{1}{2}(f(1)+f(-1)-2 f(0)), b=\frac{1}{2}$ $(f(1)-f(-1)),|a x+b|=\left|\left(\frac{1}{2} x+\frac{1}{2}\right) f(1)+\left(\frac{1}{2} x-\frac{1}{2}\right) f(-1)-x f(0)\right| \leqslant \frac{1}{2}|x+1|+$ $\frac{1}{2}|x-1|+|x| \leqslant 2$. The function $f(x)=2 x^{2}-1$ also satisfies the conditions, and $|a x+b|=|2 x| \leqslant 2$.
informal_statement: 12. $f(x)=a x^{2}+b x+c, a, b, c \in \mathbf{R}$, and when $|x| \leqslant 1$, $|f(x)| \leqslant 1$, then when $|x| \leqslant 1$, the maximum value of $|a x+b|$ is $\qquad$ .
informal_proof:
Let `P(y) = a*y² + b*y + c`. The given hypothesis is that for any real number `y` with `|y| ≤ 1`, we have `|P(y)| ≤ 1`. We aim to show that for any real number `x` with `|x| ≤ 1`, the inequality `|a*x + b| ≤ 2` holds.

Let `x` be an arbitrary real number such that `|x| ≤ 1`.
From the main hypothesis, by evaluating `P(y)` at specific points `y=1`, `y=-1`, and `y=0`, we obtain:
1.  `|P(1)| = |a + b + c| ≤ 1`
2.  `|P(-1)| = |a - b + c| ≤ 1`
3.  `|P(0)| = |c| ≤ 1`

We can express the coefficients `a` and `b` in terms of `P(1)`, `P(-1)`, and `P(0)`.
By subtracting the expression for `P(-1)` from `P(1)`, we get:
`P(1) - P(-1) = (a + b + c) - (a - b + c) = 2b`.
Thus, `b = (P(1) - P(-1)) / 2`.

By adding the expressions for `P(1)` and `P(-1)`, we get:
`P(1) + P(-1) = (a + b + c) + (a - b + c) = 2a + 2c`.
Since `c = P(0)`, we can write `2a = P(1) + P(-1) - 2P(0)`.
Thus, `a = (P(1) + P(-1) - 2P(0)) / 2`.

Now, we substitute these expressions for `a` and `b` into the term `a*x + b`:
`a*x + b = x * (P(1) + P(-1) - 2P(0)) / 2 + (P(1) - P(-1)) / 2`
`a*x + b = P(1) * (x/2 + 1/2) + P(-1) * (x/2 - 1/2) - x * P(0)`
`a*x + b = ((x+1)/2) * P(1) + ((x-1)/2) * P(-1) - x * P(0)`

To show `|a*x + b| ≤ 2`, we will prove the equivalent statement `-2 ≤ a*x + b ≤ 2`.

First, we prove the upper bound, `a*x + b ≤ 2`.
Since `|x| ≤ 1`, we have `-1 ≤ x ≤ 1`. This implies `x+1 ≥ 0` and `x-1 ≤ 0`. Also, from our initial deductions, we know `P(1) ≤ 1`, `P(-1) ≥ -1`, and `-1 ≤ P(0) ≤ 1`.
Using these inequalities, we can bound each term in the expression for `a*x + b`:
*   Since `(x+1)/2 ≥ 0` and `P(1) ≤ 1`, we have `((x+1)/2) * P(1) ≤ (x+1)/2`.
*   Since `(x-1)/2 ≤ 0` and `P(-1) ≥ -1`, we have `((x-1)/2) * P(-1) ≤ ((x-1)/2) * (-1) = (1-x)/2`.
*   The term `-x * P(0)` is bounded by `|x|`, since `|-x * P(0)| = |x| * |P(0)| ≤ |x| * 1 = |x|`. Thus, `-x * P(0) ≤ |x|`.

Summing these bounds gives:
`a*x + b ≤ (x+1)/2 + (1-x)/2 + |x| = (x+1+1-x)/2 + |x| = 1 + |x|`.
Since we assumed `|x| ≤ 1`, we have `1 + |x| ≤ 1 + 1 = 2`.
Therefore, `a*x + b ≤ 2`.

Next, we prove the lower bound, `-2 ≤ a*x + b`.
We use the same expression and inequalities. From `P(1) ≥ -1`, `P(-1) ≤ 1`, and `-1 ≤ P(0) ≤ 1`:
*   Since `(x+1)/2 ≥ 0` and `P(1) ≥ -1`, we have `((x+1)/2) * P(1) ≥ -(x+1)/2`.
*   Since `(x-1)/2 ≤ 0` and `P(-1) ≤ 1`, we have `((x-1)/2) * P(-1) ≥ (x-1)/2`.
*   The term `-x * P(0)` is bounded below by `-|x|`.

Summing these bounds gives:
`a*x + b ≥ -(x+1)/2 + (x-1)/2 - |x| = (-x-1+x-1)/2 - |x| = -1 - |x|`.
Since `|x| ≤ 1`, we have `-|x| ≥ -1`, which implies `-1 - |x| ≥ -1 - 1 = -2`.
Therefore, `a*x + b ≥ -2`.

Having established both `a*x + b ≤ 2` and `-2 ≤ a*x + b`, we can conclude that `|a*x + b| ≤ 2`. This completes the proof.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 12. $f(x)=a x^{2}+b x+c, a, b, c \in \mathbf{R}$, and when $|x| \leqslant 1$, $|f(x)| \leqslant 1$, then when $|x| \leqslant 1$, the maximum value of $|a x+b|$ is $\qquad$ . -/
theorem algebra_120864 (a b c : ℝ) (h : ∀ x : ℝ, |x| ≤ 1 → |a * x ^ 2 + b * x + c| ≤ 1) :
    ∀ x : ℝ, |x| ≤ 1 → |a * x + b| ≤ 2 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_120864 (a b c : ℝ) (h : ∀ x : ℝ, |x| ≤ 1 → |a * x ^ 2 + b * x + c| ≤ 1) :
    ∀ x : ℝ, |x| ≤ 1 → |a * x + b| ≤ 2 := by 
  intro x hx
  have h1 := h 1 (by norm_num)
  have h2 := h (-1) (by norm_num)
  have h3 := h 0 (by norm_num)
  have h4 := h x (by 
    simpa using hx
  )
  cases' abs_le.mp h1 with h1_neg h1_pos
  cases' abs_le.mp h2 with h2_neg h2_pos
  cases' abs_le.mp h3 with h3_neg h3_pos
  cases' abs_le.mp h4 with h4_neg h4_pos
  have hx1 : -1 ≤ x := by linarith [abs_le.mp hx]
  have hx2 : x ≤ 1 := by linarith [abs_le.mp hx]
  have h5 : -2 ≤ a * x + b := by

soln_description: Solution: Choose B. Reason: The graph of the first function is symmetric to the graph of the second function about $x-y=0$, and the graph of the second function is symmetric to the graph of the third function about $x+y=0$, so the graph of the first function is symmetric to the graph of the third function about the origin.
informal_statement:
Example 4 (1988 National High School League Question) There are three functions, the first one is $y=\varphi(x)$, its inverse function is the second function, and the graph of the third function is symmetrical to the graph of the second function about the line $x+y=0$, then the third function is ( ).
A. $y=-\varphi(x)$
B. $y=-\varphi(-x)$
C. $y=-\varphi^{-1}(x)$
D. $y=-\varphi^{-1}(-x)$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 4 (1988 National High School League Question) There are three functions, the first one is $y=\varphi(x)$, its inverse function is the second function, and the graph of the third function is symmetrical to the graph of the second function about the line $x+y=0$, then the third function is ( ).
A. $y=-\varphi(x)$
B. $y=-\varphi(-x)$
C. $y=-\varphi^{-1}(x)$
D. $y=-\varphi^{-1}(-x)$ -/
theorem algebra_197500 {φ g h : ℝ → ℝ}
    (hf : Function.LeftInverse g φ)
    (hg : Function.RightInverse g φ)
    (hgh : ∀ x, ∃ y, h x = -g y ∧ g y = -x) :
    h = fun x => -g (-x) := by

soln_description:
## Solution.

The equation from the statement can also be written as $\left(x+\frac{k}{2}\right)^{2}=\left(y+\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2}+\frac{k^{2}-1}{4}$, or, by factoring:

$$
\left(x-y+\frac{k-1}{2}\right) \cdot\left(x+y+\frac{k+1}{2}\right)=\frac{k^{2}-1}{4}
$$

We distinguish two cases based on the parity of $k$. If $k$ is odd, we write $k=2 a+1$ and the previous equation becomes $(x-y+a)(x+y+a+1)=a(a+1)$. By setting the first factor to 1 and the second to $a(a+1)$, we get $x=\frac{a(a-1)}{2}$ and $y=x+(a-1)=\frac{(a-1)(a+2)}{2}$. Given that the product of two consecutive integers is always even, the values we have obtained form a solution as soon as $a>1$. For $a=1$ (i.e., $k=3$), on the contrary, there is no solution, because the equality $(x-y+1)(x+y+2)=2$ cannot be satisfied given that the second factor is always $>2$ when $x$ and $y$ are strictly positive. For $a=0$, finally, we have $k=1$ and, clearly, all pairs $(x, y)$ are suitable.

We reason similarly in the case where $k$ is even. We set $k=2 a$ and equation (2) becomes $(2 x-2 y+2 a-1)(2 x+2 y+2 a+1)=4 a^{2}-1$. As before, by setting the first factor to 1, we obtain a system in $x$ and $y$ whose solutions are $x=a(a-1)$ and $y=(a+1)(a-1)$. This solution is acceptable as soon as $a>1$. For $a=1$, the equation to solve becomes $(2 x-2 y+1)(2 x+2 y+3)=3$ and it has no solution with $x, y>0$ given that this condition implies that the second factor is $>3$.

In summary, the integers $k$ that work are $k=1$ and all integers $k \geqslant 4$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_06_04_6c96fb1ce2d0d58c89f6g-09.jpg?height=95&width=203&top_left_y=1465&top_left_x=950)
informal_statement:
Exercise 8. Find all natural numbers $\mathrm{k}>0$ such that the equation in $x$ and $\mathrm{y}$:

$$
x(x+k)=y(y+1)
$$

has a solution in strictly positive integers.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Exercise 8. Find all natural numbers $\mathrm{k}>0$ such that the equation in $x$ and $\mathrm{y}$:

$$
x(x+k)=y(y+1)
$$

has a solution in strictly positive integers. -/
theorem number_theory_292581 (k : ℕ) :
    (k > 0 ∧ ∃ x y : ℕ, x > 0 ∧ y > 0 ∧ x * (x + k) = y * (y + 1)) ↔ k ≥ 4 := by

soln_description:
$$
\begin{array}{l}
=\frac{1999^{2 x-1}}{1999^{2 x-1}-1}+\frac{1999^{1-2 x}}{1999^{1-2 x}-1}=1 \\
\therefore \sum_{i=1}^{4000} f\left(\frac{i}{4001}\right)=\sum_{i=1}^{2000}\left[f\left(\frac{i}{4001}\right)+f\left(\frac{4001-i}{4001}\right)\right] \\
=\sum_{i=1}^{2000}\left[f\left(\frac{i}{4001}\right)+f\left(1-\frac{i}{4001}\right)\right] \\
=\sum_{i=1}^{2000} 1=2000 . \\
2.2000 .
\end{array}
$$

It is easy to see that $f(x)=\frac{1999^{2 x-1}}{1999^{2 x-1}-1}$.
Also, $f(x)+f(1-x)$
informal_statement: 2. Given the function $f(x+1)=\frac{1999^{2 x+1}}{1999^{2 x+1}-1}$. Then the value of the sum $\sum_{i=1}^{4000} f\left(\frac{i}{4001}\right)$ is $\qquad$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 2. Given the function $f(x+1)=\frac{1999^{2 x+1}}{1999^{2 x+1}-1}$. Then the value of the sum $\sum_{i=1}^{4000} f\left(\frac{i}{4001}\right)$ is $\qquad$ -/
theorem algebra_319554 {f : ℝ → ℝ} (hf : ∀ x, f (x + 1) = 1999^(2 * x + 1) / (1999^(2 * x + 1) - 1)) :
    ∑ i ∈ Finset.range 4000, f ((i + 1) / 4001) = 2000 := by

informal_statement: A geometric sequence of positive integers is formed for which the first term is 2 and the fifth term is 162. What is the sixth term of the sequence?
informal_proof:
Let the geometric sequence be denoted by `u_n`, where the first term is `a` and the common ratio is `r`. We are given that `a` and `r` are positive integers. The `n`-th term of the sequence is given by `a * r^(n-1)`.

We are given that the first term is 2, so `a = 2`.
We are also given that the fifth term is 162, which means `a * r^(5-1) = 162`, or `a * r^4 = 162`.
Our goal is to find the sixth term, which is `a * r^(6-1) = a * r^5`.

First, we substitute the value `a = 2` into the equation for the fifth term:
`2 * r^4 = 162`

Dividing both sides of this equation by 2, we find:
`r^4 = 81`

Now, we must determine the value of the positive integer `r`. We will show that `r` must be 3. First, we establish an upper bound for `r` by showing `r ≤ 3`. We argue by contradiction. Assume that `r > 3`. Since `r` is an integer, this is equivalent to `r ≥ 4`. If `r ≥ 4`, then raising both sides to the power of 4 (which is a strictly increasing function for positive bases), we get:
`r^4 ≥ 4^4`
`r^4 ≥ 256`

This contradicts our finding that `r^4 = 81`, as `81` is not greater than or equal to `256`. Therefore, our assumption that `r > 3` must be false, and we conclude that `r ≤ 3`.

Since we are given that `r` is a positive integer, we have `r > 0`. Combining this with `r ≤ 3`, the only possible integer values for `r` are 1, 2, and 3. We check which of these values satisfies `r^4 = 81`:
- If `r = 1`, then `r^4 = 1^4 = 1 ≠ 81`.
- If `r = 2`, then `r^4 = 2^4 = 16 ≠ 81`.
- If `r = 3`, then `r^4 = 3^4 = 81`.

The only possibility is `r = 3`.

Finally, we calculate the value of the sixth term, `a * r^5`, using the known values `a = 2` and `r = 3`:
`a * r^5 = 2 * 3^5`
Since `3^5 = 243`, we have:
`2 * 243 = 486`

Thus, the sixth term of the sequence is 486.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- A geometric sequence of positive integers is formed for which the first term is 2 and the fifth term is 162. What is the sixth term of the sequence? -/
theorem algebra_10258 (a r : ℤ) (h₀ : 0 < a) (h₁ : 0 < r) (h₂ : a = 2) (h₃ : a * r ^ 4 = 162) :
    a * r ^ 5 = 486 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_10258 (a r : ℤ) (h₀ : 0 < a) (h₁ : 0 < r) (h₂ : a = 2) (h₃ : a * r ^ 4 = 162) :
    a * r ^ 5 = 486 := by
  rw [h₂] at h₃
  have h4 : r ^ 4 = 81 := by
    nlinarith
  have hr : r = 3 := by
    have h5 : r ^ 4 = 81 := h4
    have h6 : r ≤ 3 := by
      by_contra h
      push_neg at h
      have h7 : r ≥ 4 := by omega
      have h8 : r ^ 4 ≥ 256 := by
        have h9 : r ≥ 4 := h7
        have h10 : r ^ 4 ≥ (4 : ℤ) ^ 4 := by
          apply pow_le_pow_left
          all_goals nlinarith
        have h11 : (4 : ℤ) ^ 4 = 256 := by
          norm_num
        linarith
      nlinarith
    interval_cases r <;> omega
  rw [h₂, hr]
  norm_num

informal_statement:
Problem 2. We say a positive integer $n$ is lovely if there exist a positive integer $k$ and (not necessarily distinct) positive integers $d_{1}, d_{2}, \ldots, d_{k}$ such that $n=d_{1} d_{2} \ldots d_{k}$ and

$$
d_{i}^{2} \mid n+d_{i}
$$

for all $i \in\{1, \ldots, k\}$.

(a) Are there infinitely many lovely numbers?

(b) Does there exist a lovely number greater than 1 which is a square of an integer?

(Ivan Novak)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

def isLovely (n : ℕ) := ∃ k > 0, ∃ d : Fin k → ℕ,
    (∀ i, d i > 0) ∧
    (∀ i, (d i)^2 ∣ n + d i) ∧
    n = ∏ i, d i

/- Problem 2. We say a positive integer $n$ is lovely if there exist a positive integer $k$ and (not necessarily distinct) positive integers $d_{1}, d_{2}, \ldots, d_{k}$ such that $n=d_{1} d_{2} \ldots d_{k}$ and

$$
d_{i}^{2} \mid n+d_{i}
$$

for all $i \in\{1, \ldots, k\}$.

(a) Are there infinitely many lovely numbers?

(b) Does there exist a lovely number greater than 1 which is a square of an integer?

(Ivan Novak) -/
theorem number_theory_244294 :
    (∀ N, ∃ n, n > N ∧ isLovely n) ∧
    ∃ m, m > 1 ∧ isLovely m ∧ ∃ p, m = p^2 := by

soln_description:
1. Consider the product given in the problem:
   \[
   \prod_{i=1}^{n} \left( 4 - \frac{2}{i} \right)
   \]

2. Simplify each term inside the product:
   \[
   4 - \frac{2}{i} = \frac{4i - 2}{i} = \frac{2(2i - 1)}{i}
   \]

3. Rewrite the product using the simplified terms:
   \[
   \prod_{i=1}^{n} \left( 4 - \frac{2}{i} \right) = \prod_{i=1}^{n} \frac{2(2i - 1)}{i}
   \]

4. Separate the product into two parts:
   \[
   \prod_{i=1}^{n} \frac{2(2i - 1)}{i} = 2^n \prod_{i=1}^{n} \frac{2i - 1}{i}
   \]

5. Express the product of fractions as a single fraction:
   \[
   \prod_{i=1}^{n} \frac{2i - 1}{i} = \frac{(2 \cdot 1 - 1)(2 \cdot 2 - 1) \cdots (2n - 1)}{1 \cdot 2 \cdot 3 \cdots n} = \frac{(2n - 1)!!}{n!}
   \]
   Here, \((2n - 1)!!\) denotes the double factorial of \((2n - 1)\), which is the product of all odd numbers up to \((2n - 1)\).

6. Combine the results:
   \[
   \prod_{i=1}^{n} \left( 4 - \frac{2}{i} \right) = 2^n \cdot \frac{(2n - 1)!!}{n!}
   \]

7. Recognize that \((2n - 1)!!\) can be expressed in terms of factorials:
   \[
   (2n - 1)!! = \frac{(2n)!}{2^n n!}
   \]

8. Substitute this expression back into the product:
   \[
   2^n \cdot \frac{(2n - 1)!!}{n!} = 2^n \cdot \frac{\frac{(2n)!}{2^n n!}}{n!} = \frac{(2n)!}{n! n!}
   \]

9. Recognize that \(\frac{(2n)!}{n! n!}\) is the binomial coefficient \(\binom{2n}{n}\), which is known to be an integer:
   \[
   \binom{2n}{n} = \frac{(2n)!}{n! n!}
   \]

10. Therefore, the product \(\prod_{i=1}^{n} \left( 4 - \frac{2}{i} \right)\) is an integer.

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement: Show that for every natural number $n$ the product \[\left( 4-\frac{2}{1}\right) \left( 4-\frac{2}{2}\right) \left( 4-\frac{2}{3}\right) \cdots \left( 4-\frac{2}{n}\right)\] is an integer.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Show that for every natural number $n$ the product \[\left( 4-\frac{2}{1}\right) \left( 4-\frac{2}{2}\right) \left( 4-\frac{2}{3}\right) \cdots \left( 4-\frac{2}{n}\right)\] is an integer. -/
theorem number_theory_68753 (n : ℕ) :
    ∃ k : ℤ, ∏ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 n, (4 - 2 / i : ℚ) = k := by

soln_description:
Three, 15. Since $x y=x z+3$, therefore, $x(y-z)=3$.
Also, $x, y, z$ are all positive integers, then
$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x = 3, \\
y - z = 1
\end{array} \text { or } \left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=1, \\
y-z=3 .
\end{array}\right.\right.
$$
(1) When $\left\{\begin{array}{l}x=3, \\ y=z+1\end{array}\right.$, by $y z=x y+x z-7$, that is
$$
(z+1) z=3(z+1)+3 z-7,
$$

rearranging gives
$$
z^{2}-5 z+4=0 .
$$

Thus, the surface area of the rectangular box is
$$
\begin{array}{l}
2(x y+x z+y z) \\
=2(3 \times 2+3 \times 1+2 \times 1)=22\left(\mathrm{~cm}^{2}\right),
\end{array}
$$

or $2(x y+x z+y z)$
$$
=2(3 \times 5+3 \times 4+5 \times 4)=94\left(\mathrm{~cm}^{2}\right) \text { (discard). }
$$
(2) When $\left\{\begin{array}{l}x=1, \\ y=z+3\end{array}\right.$, by $y z=x y+x z-7$, that is
$$
(z+3) z=z+3+z-7,
$$

rearranging gives
$$
z^{2}+z+4=0 .
$$

This equation has no real solutions.
Therefore, to make such a box, at least $22 \mathrm{~cm}^{2}$ of cardboard is needed.
informal_statement: 15. (16 points) In an activity class, the teacher asked each student to make a rectangular box with a lid as shown in Figure 6. The length, width, and height of the rectangular box are $x \mathrm{~cm}, y \mathrm{~cm}$, and $z \mathrm{~cm}$, respectively. When Xiao Yang presented his box, he told the class: “The length, width, and height of the box I made are all positive integers, and upon measurement, they satisfy $x y=x z+3, y z=x y+x z-7$." Please calculate how many square centimeters of cardboard are needed to make such a box (ignoring the seams)?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 15. (16 points) In an activity class, the teacher asked each student to make a rectangular box with a lid as shown in Figure 6. The length, width, and height of the rectangular box are $x \mathrm{~cm}, y \mathrm{~cm}$, and $z \mathrm{~cm}$, respectively. When Xiao Yang presented his box, he told the class: “The length, width, and height of the box I made are all positive integers, and upon measurement, they satisfy $x y=x z+3, y z=x y+x z-7$." Please calculate how many square centimeters of cardboard are needed to make such a box (ignoring the seams)? -/
theorem algebra_298197 {x y z : ℕ} (hx : 0 < x) (hy : 0 < y) (hz : 0 < z)
    (h1 : x * y = x * z + 3) (h2 : y * z = x * y + x * z - 7) :
    2 * (x * y + y * z + x * z) = 22 := by

informal_statement: 8. Given $y=y_{1}+y_{2}, y_{1}$ is directly proportional to $x$, $y_{2}$ is inversely proportional to $x^{2}$, and when $x=2$ and $x=3$, the value of $y$ is 19. Find the functional relationship between $y$ and $x$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 8. Given $y=y_{1}+y_{2}, y_{1}$ is directly proportional to $x$, $y_{2}$ is inversely proportional to $x^{2}$, and when $x=2$ and $x=3$, the value of $y$ is 19. Find the functional relationship between $y$ and $x$. -/
theorem algebra_328203 {y : ℝ → ℝ} (hy : ∃ y1 y2, y = y1 + y2 ∧
    (∃ k, y1 = k * x) ∧ (∃ m, y2 = m / x ^ 2) ∧ y 2 = 19 ∧ y 3 = 19) :
    y = fun x => 5 * x + 36 / x ^ 2 := by

informal_statement: Prove that there are infinitely many pairs of natural numbers $a$ and $b$ such that $a^2 + 1$ is divisible by $b$ and $b^2 + 1$ is divisible by $a$ .
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Prove that there are infinitely many pairs of natural numbers $a$ and $b$ such that $a^2 + 1$ is divisible by $b$ and $b^2 + 1$ is divisible by $a$ .
 -/
theorem number_theory_66174 :
    ∀ n : ℕ, ∃ a b : ℕ,
      a > n ∧ b > n ∧ b ∣ a ^ 2 + 1 ∧ a ∣ b ^ 2 + 1 := by

informal_statement: If $m$ and $n$ are both positive integers, and ${{m}^{2}}={{n}^{2}}+2020$, find the smallest possible value of $m$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- If $m$ and $n$ are both positive integers, and ${{m}^{2}}={{n}^{2}}+2020$, find the smallest possible value of $m$. -/
theorem number_theory_3118 (m n : ℕ) (h₀ : 0 < m) (h₁ : 0 < n) (h₂ : m ^ 2 = n ^ 2 + 2020) :
    IsLeast {x | ∃ m n : ℕ, 0 < m ∧ 0 < n ∧ m ^ 2 = n ^ 2 + 2020 ∧ x = m} 106 := by

soln_description:
The function's domain is $-\frac{1}{2} \leqslant x \leqslant \frac{1}{2}$. The function can be transformed as follows:
$$
\begin{array}{l}
y=16 \sqrt{\frac{1}{2}-x}+9 \sqrt{x+\frac{1}{2}} . \\
\text { Let } x_{0}=\sqrt{\frac{1}{2}-x} \quad(0 \leqslant x_{0} \leqslant 1), \\
y_{0}=\sqrt{x+\frac{1}{2}} \quad\left(0 \leqslant y_{0} \leqslant 1\right) .
\end{array}
$$

Then $x_{0}^2 + y_{0}^2 = 1$.
Consider $\left(x_{0}, y_{0}\right)$ as a point on the arc of a circle, and the original function can be transformed as:
$$
y=16 x_{0}+9 y_{0} \text {. }
$$

Recall the point-to-line distance formula:
$$
d=\frac{\left|A x_{0}+B y_{0}+C\right|}{\sqrt{A^{2}+B^{2}}},
$$

Then the original function can be transformed as:
$$
y=\sqrt{16^{2}+9^{2}} \cdot \frac{16 x_{0}+9 y_{0}}{\sqrt{16^{2}+9^{2}}},
$$

where $x_{0}^2 + y_{0}^2 = 1$. Let
$$
d'=\frac{16 x_{0}+9 y_{0}}{\sqrt{16^{2}+9^{2}}}>0 \text {, }
$$
$d'$ represents the distance from a point on the arc to the line $16 x + 9 y = 0$, and we have:
$$
y=\sqrt{16^{2}+9^{2}} \cdot d' \text {. }
$$

As shown in the figure, we have:
$$
\begin{array}{l}
d'_{(A) \text { min }}=\frac{16 \times 0+9 \times 1}{\sqrt{16^{2}+9^{2}}}=\frac{9}{\sqrt{337}}, \\
d'_{(C) \text { max }}=1 .
\end{array}
$$

By the continuity of the curve, we have:
$$
d' \in\left[\frac{9}{\sqrt{337}}, 1\right] \text {. }
$$

Substituting $y=\sqrt{16^{2}+9^{2}} d'$, we can find the range of the function $y \in[9, \sqrt{337}]$.
Therefore, for any function of the form
$$
y=A \sqrt{a x+b}+B \sqrt{c x+d}
$$

the function can be transformed as follows:
(1) When $a c > 0$, the function can be transformed as:
$$
y=m \sqrt{x+p}+n \sqrt{x+q} \text {, }
$$

where $x \geqslant -p, y \geqslant -q$.
Let $x_{0}=\sqrt{x+p}, y_{0}=\sqrt{x+q}$. Then
$$
x_{0}^2 - y_{0}^2 = p - q \text {. }
$$

Then consider the distance from a point on a segment of a hyperbola to the line $m x + n y = 0$, and the range can be found.

In addition, for any function of the form $y=A \sqrt{a x+b}+B x$, it can also be transformed as:
$$
y=m \sqrt{x+p}+B x(a>0),
$$

or $y=m \sqrt{p-x}+B x(a<0)$.
Let $x_{0}=\sqrt{x+p}$ (or $x_{0}=\sqrt{p-x}$ ),
$$
y_{0}=x \text {. }
$$

Then $x_{0}^2 - y_{0} = p$ (or $x_{0}^2 + y_{0} = p$) (considering a segment of a parabola), and the original function can be transformed as:
$$
y=m x_{0}+B y_{0} \text {. }
$$

Then by finding the distance from a point on a segment of a parabola to a line, the range of the original function can be determined.
informal_statement: Example. Find the range of the function $y=4 \sqrt{8-16 x}$ $+3 \sqrt{9 x-\frac{9}{2}}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- Example. Find the range of the function $y=4 \sqrt{8-16 x}$ $+3 \sqrt{9 x-\frac{9}{2}}$. -/
theorem algebra_309461 (f : ℝ → ℝ)
  (hf : f = λ x => 4 * sqrt (8 - 16 * x) + 3 * sqrt (9 * x - 9 / 2)) :
  range f = {y | 9 ≤ y ∧ y ≤ sqrt 337} :=

informal_statement: Voor positieve gehele getallen $a$ en $b$ definiëren we $a \ominus b=\frac{a-b}{\operatorname{ggd}(a, b)}$. Bewijs dat voor elk geheel getal $n>1$ geldt: $n$ is een priemmacht (d.w.z. dat $n$ te schrijven is als $n=p^{k}$ met $p$ een priemgetal en $k$ een positief geheel getal) dan en slechts dan als voor alle positieve gehele $m<n$ geldt dat $\operatorname{ggd}(n, n \ominus m)=1$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Voor positieve gehele getallen $a$ en $b$ definiëren we $a \ominus b=\frac{a-b}{\operatorname{ggd}(a, b)}$. Bewijs dat voor elk geheel getal $n>1$ geldt: $n$ is een priemmacht (d.w.z. dat $n$ te schrijven is als $n=p^{k}$ met $p$ een priemgetal en $k$ een positief geheel getal) dan en slechts dan als voor alle positieve gehele $m<n$ geldt dat $\operatorname{ggd}(n, n \ominus m)=1$. -/
theorem number_theory_604893 {n : ℕ} (hn : 1 < n) :
    (∃ p k, p.Prime ∧ n = p ^ k) ↔ ∀ m, 0 < m → m < n → Nat.gcd n ((n - m) / Nat.gcd n m) = 1 := by

soln_description:
[Proof] In the equation
$$a x^{2}+b x+c=0$$

let $x=y / a$, and then multiply both sides by $a$, obtaining the equation with integer coefficients
$$y^{2}+b y+a c=0$$

If $x$ is a rational number, then the number $y=a x$ is also a rational number. Therefore, equation (2) has a rational root just like equation (1). We know that if an equation with integer coefficients and a leading coefficient of 1 has a rational root, then this rational root must be an integer. Therefore, equation (2) has an integer root $y_{1}$. Thus, the other root of equation (2), $-b-y_{1}$, is also an integer. Since
$$y_{1}+y_{2}=-b, y_{1} y_{2}=a c,$$

we have
$$a b c=-y_{1} y_{2}\left(y_{1}+y_{2}\right)$$

Among the numbers $y_{1}, y_{2},\left(y_{1}+y_{2}\right)$, at least one is even, so the product $a b c$ is even. Therefore, at least one of $a, b, c$ is even.
informal_statement:
4・6 Prove: If the quadratic equation with integer coefficients
$$a x^{2}+b x+c=0 \quad(a \neq 0)$$

has a rational root, then at least one of the numbers $a, b, c$ is even.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 4・6 Prove: If the quadratic equation with integer coefficients
$$a x^{2}+b x+c=0 \quad(a \neq 0)$$

has a rational root, then at least one of the numbers $a, b, c$ is even. -/
theorem algebra_598529 {a b c : ℤ} (ha : a ≠ 0) (h : ∃ x : ℚ, a * x ^ 2 + b * x + c = 0) :
    Even a ∨ Even b ∨ Even c := by

soln_description:
Let's first write the equation in the form: $7^{x}-1=3 \times 2^{y}$. The solution involves factorizations, notably: $7^{x}-1=(7-1)\left(7^{x-1}+7^{x-2}+\cdots+7+1\right)$. Since $7-1=3 \times 2$, the equation becomes: $7^{x-1}+7^{x-2}+\cdots+7+1=2^{y-1}$. Either $y=1$, which provides a first solution $(x=y=1)$, or the right-hand side is even and the left-hand side contains an even number of terms (all odd), so $x$ is even. From there, we can factorize again by $(7+1)=2^{3}$, which brings us to: $7^{x-2}+7^{x-4}+\cdots+7^{2}+1=2^{y-4}$. Once again, either $y=4$ which provides a second solution $(x=2)$, or both sides are even, so the first contains an even number of terms, $x$ is a multiple of 4. We can factorize the first member again as: $\left(7^{2}+1\right)\left(7^{x-4}+7^{x-8}+\ldots+7^{4}+1\right)$. But this time, $7^{2}+1=50$ cannot divide the second member which is a power of 2, so there is no solution for $y>4$. The only solutions are $(1,1)$ and $(2,4)$.
